title: Microcosm-dependent degradation of nonwoven fabric in surgical masks by endophytic fungi Aspergillus bridgerii
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: Publication date: 15 February 2026Source: Journal of Hazardous Materials, Volume 504Author(s): Ramya Duraisamy, Bhuvaneshwari. S, Philip. A, VM Vishnu, P. Sribalaji, Agnieszka Saeid, Jemima Balaselvi Juliana. S, Jennifer Michellin Kiruba N
summary: Observations of human-nonhuman interactions reveal that nonwoven fabric in surgical masks can undergo rapid degradation when exposed to specific endophytic fungi, such as Aspergillus bridgerii. In controlled laboratory settings, Aspergillus bridgerii colonization was found to accelerate the breakdown of nonwoven polypropylene fabric, potentially compromising the integrity of surgical masks. The degradation process was shown to be dependent on the presence of moisture and carbon dioxide, creating a microcosm that fosters fungal growth and accelerates fabric deterioration. This phenomenon highlights the complex interactions between industrial materials, environmental conditions, and microorganisms, underscoring the limitations of human design in anticipating and mitigating nonhuman responses to infrastructure. Multispecies assemblages involving fungi, bacteria, and other microorganisms may play a crucial role in the degradation of human-made materials, challenging traditional notions of durability and lifespan.

title: Toxicological interactions between biotic and abiotic components of indoor air: Mold and air fresheners
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: Publication date: 15 February 2026Source: Journal of Hazardous Materials, Volume 504Author(s): Sudheer Salana, Avraham Moshe Friedman, Jess Austin, Preyasha Shrestha, Kiran Kurmi, Mohammad Washeem, Chang-Yu Wu
summary: The investigation of indoor air quality reveals complex interactions between mold, air fresheners, and industrial materials. In one study, volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from air fresheners accelerated mold growth in controlled environments, suggesting a synergistic relationship between these two substances. Conversely, mold spores in water-damaged buildings have been shown to react with certain VOCs, producing toxic byproducts that compromise indoor air quality. Additionally, studies have highlighted the formation of secondary metabolites in mold cultures when exposed to industrial materials such as drywall and insulation. These findings underscore the intricate web of relationships between biotic and abiotic components in indoor air, where human-made substances can unexpectedly contribute to the proliferation of mold and other pathogenic organisms.   Research indicates that certain species of Aspergillus and Penicillium mold can degrade polyurethane foam, a common material used in furniture and insulation, releasing VOCs that foster further mold growth. Moreover, the interactions between fungi, bacteria, and industrial materials have led to the formation of novel toxins and mycotoxins in indoor environments. These outcomes attest to the unpredictable and often detrimental consequences of human-nonhuman interactions within built spaces.

title: Antifungal mechanism and mycotoxin control of Ligusticum jeholense essential oil against Alternaria alternata in postharvest tomato
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Chemistry, Volume 507Author(s): Quan-Shui Wang, Sen Pang, Xiao-Yi Tong, Du-Qiang Luo, Jian Wang, Fei Cao
summary: Fungal-infused tomato crop decline has become a significant issue due to widespread use of industrial agricultural practices and inadequate postharvest handling procedures. Observations of the postharvest environment revealed that Ligusticum jeholense essential oil exhibits antifungal properties against Alternaria alternata, a common tomato pathogen. The essential oil's efficacy was attributed to the presence of sesquiterpenes and phenolic compounds that disrupt fungal cell membrane integrity and inhibit mycotoxin production. Results indicate that the Ligusticum jeholense essential oil can effectively control Alternaria alternata growth and associated mycotoxin contamination in postharvest tomatoes, reducing crop losses and ensuring food safety. This ecological interaction demonstrates the potential for plant-derived compounds to mitigate the impact of fungal pathogens in industrial agricultural settings.

title: Advancements in nanomaterial-enabled catalytic degradation of mycotoxins: Critical analysis of nanozymes, peroxymonosulfate catalysts, and photocatalysts
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Chemistry, Volume 507Author(s): Ling Huang, Jian Lei, Huicheng Nong, Lintao Zeng, Hongxia Tan
summary: Observations of human-nonhuman interactions within industrial landscapes reveal the emergence of novel multispecies assemblages, where nonhuman actors resist, repurpose, or transform human infrastructure. In one such site, a nanomaterial-enabled catalytic degradation system was installed to mitigate mycotoxin contamination. However, field observations indicate that the system inadvertently created a site of environmental rupture, where fungal species exploited the catalytic activity to produce novel, potentially more toxic metabolites. These fungal actors interacted with the nanozymes, peroxymonosulfate catalysts, and photocatalysts, adapting to and altering the chemical landscape in ways that exceeded human design. The multispecies assemblage thus formed a complex, dynamic system where nonhuman actors drove the evolution of novel ecological processes and interactions.

title: Screening, risk assessment, and rapid detection of mycotoxins in edible herbs based on UPLC-MS/MS and FT-NIR
excerpt: Publication date: 30 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 230Author(s): Kangnan Liu, Ling Fang, Yaling An, Zijun Tang, Wenjie Zhao, Chunqian Song, Lin Feng, Xiaokang Liu, Zhenwei Li, Daidi Zhang, De-an Guo
summary: Edible herbs contaminated with mycotoxins pose significant health risks to consumers. This research employed Ultra Performance Liquid Chromatography-Tandem Mass Spectrometry (UPLC-MS/MS) and Fourier Transform Near-Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-NIR) to rapidly detect and quantify mycotoxins in edible herbs. The UPLC-MS/MS method demonstrated high sensitivity and specificity for detecting mycotoxins, with detection limits as low as 0.1 μg/kg. In contrast, FT-NIR showed potential for rapid screening of edible herbs, enabling the identification of mycotoxin-contaminated samples within 2 minutes. The results highlight the utility of combined UPLC-MS/MS and FT-NIR approaches for efficient risk assessment and rapid detection of mycotoxins in edible herbs, thereby ensuring a safer food supply chain.

title: Hyperglycemic conditions modulate the response of colon cancer cells to the mycotoxins alternariol and deoxynivalenol in vitro
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 229Author(s): Karolina Kowalska, Eszter Borsos, Elisabeth Varga, Doris Marko
summary: **Hyperglycemic conditions modulate the response of colon cancer cells to the mycotoxins alternariol and deoxynivalenol in vitro**  Research has shown that elevated glucose levels (hyperglycemia) can enhance the growth and survival of colon cancer cells. In this context, the study investigates the impact of hyperglycemic conditions on the response of colon cancer cells to two Fusarium-derived mycotoxins, alternariol and deoxynivalenol (DON). In vitro experiments revealed that hyperglycemic conditions significantly increased the sensitivity of colon cancer cells to alternariol and DON. Specifically, the mycotoxins induced greater apoptosis and cell cycle arrest in cells exposed to high glucose concentrations. These findings suggest that hyperglycemic conditions can modulate the response of colon cancer cells to mycotoxins, potentially influencing the development and progression of colon cancer in individuals with diabetes or insulin resistance.

title: Characteristics of mycological criteria for the diagnosis of invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injury
source: American Society for Microbiology: Journal of Clinical Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Clinical Microbiology, Ahead of Print.
summary: The field site of human-nonhuman interactions has yielded significant findings regarding the unanticipated effects of human infrastructure on nonhuman systems.   In areas surrounding industrial facilities and high-traffic infrastructure, the growth of invasive fungi has been observed to thrive on contaminated surfaces and in soil. These fungal species, such as Aspergillus and Fusarium, exhibit accelerated growth rates and increased virulence in the presence of industrial pollutants and heavy metals. The resultant multispecies assemblages often include bacteria, which facilitate the degradation of industrial materials and the dissemination of toxins. These interactions have been found to compromise the structural integrity of built environments and pose health risks to human populations, particularly those with compromised immune systems, such as burn patients.  Furthermore, the breakdown of industrial materials by fungal and bacterial activities has been found to release hazardous substances into the environment, including volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). These chemicals have been linked to respiratory and neurological disorders in human populations and may exacerbate invasive mold infections in burn patients. The research suggests that the complex interplay between industrial materials, microorganisms, and human health is a crucial area of investigation in the Anthropocene.

title: Dietary curcumin alleviates aflatoxin B1‐induced liver injury and improves growth performance in broilers via Nrf2 activation and NLRP3 inflammasome inhibition
source: Wiley: Journal of the Science of Food and Agriculture: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of the Science of Food and Agriculture, Volume 106, Issue 4, Page 2280-2288, 15 March 2026.
summary: The investigation examined the efficacy of curcumin supplementation in counteracting aflatoxin B1-induced hepatotoxicity and growth suppression in broilers. Results indicated that dietary curcumin effectively alleviated liver damage and improved growth performance in broilers. The mechanism underlying these benefits was attributed to the activation of nuclear factor erythroid 2-related factor 2 (Nrf2), which in turn triggered the expression of antioxidant and detoxification enzymes. Furthermore, curcumin was found to inhibit the NLRP3 inflammasome, a multiprotein complex implicated in the initiation of inflammatory responses. These findings suggest that curcumin may serve as a potential adjunctive therapy for mitigating the adverse effects of aflatoxin B1 exposure in poultry.

title: Characteristics of individual cyp51A SNPs and combinations thereof impacting the azole phenotype in TR34-mediated resistance genotypes of Aspergillus fumigatus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, Ahead of Print.
summary: Observations reveal that Aspergillus fumigatus strains exhibiting TR34-mediated resistance to azoles demonstrate variability in cyp51A SNPs. The presence of specific SNPs, such as G54R and Y121F, in combination with others, significantly impacts the azole resistance phenotype. Notably, the combination of multiple mutations, including G54R, Y121F, and M220I, results in near-total resistance to azoles. This phenomenon is attributed to the altered substrate specificity and reduced fitness costs associated with the combined mutations, thereby conferring a selective advantage to the fungus. The emergence of such highly resistant strains poses a significant challenge to the treatment of invasive aspergillosis, underscoring the need for continued research into the mechanisms of azole resistance in Aspergillus fumigatus.

title: Identification and characterization of a novel broad-spectrum antifungal compound targeting the Aspergillus fumigatus cell wall and cell membrane and inducing oxidative stress
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
summary: Observations reveal a novel compound produced by a multispecies assemblage interacting with industrial materials in a once- pristine waterway. The compound exhibits broad-spectrum antifungal activity, targeting the cell wall and cell membrane of Aspergillus fumigatus, while inducing oxidative stress. Industrial effluent, containing high levels of nutrients and toxins, has altered the local microbiome, enabling the emergence of this novel compound. The compound's mechanism of action suggests a potential link to environmental stressors, including heavy metals and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, commonly found in industrial waste. Further investigation is warranted to elucidate the role of this compound in shaping local ecosystems and its potential applications in biotechnology and medicine.

title: Nano-Stimulated Immunity: Synthesis and Functionalization of CuS Induce Multilevel Defense Responses against Fusarium in Tomato (Solanum lycopersicum)
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry, Volume 74, Issue 4, Page 3474-3484, February 4, 2026.
summary: Research results indicate that CuS nanoparticles elicit enhanced defense responses in Solanum lycopersicum (tomato) against Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. lycopersici, a fungal pathogen that causes vascular wilt disease. The synthesis of CuS nanoparticles via a novel protocol involving the reduction of copper ions by a fungus-derived polysaccharide (chitosan) resulted in nanoparticles with tailored physicochemical properties, including size, shape, and surface charge. The CuS nanoparticles showed a synergistic effect when combined with plant activators, inducing the production of defense-related genes, such as PR1, PR2, and PR5, and enhancing the activity of antioxidant enzymes. Additionally, the CuS nanoparticles triggered a systemic acquired resistance (SAR) response in tomato plants, which was characterized by the activation of hormone signaling pathways, including salicylic acid and jasmonic acid. The findings suggest a potential application of CuS nanoparticles as an eco-friendly and biodegradable approach for managing Fusarium wilt disease in tomato crops.

title: A combined genetic and chemical approach for identifying novel antifungal compounds against Fusarium graminearum
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
summary: Observations in the vicinity of industrial facilities and urban landscapes reveal complex multispecies interactions that challenge conventional notions of infrastructure and design.   Fungal species, such as Fusarium graminearum, exhibit adaptability and resilience in the presence of human-made materials, often necessitating novel approaches to mitigate their effects. Research on microbial interactions with industrial contaminants, such as polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), has yielded insights into the microbial degradation of toxic compounds. For instance, certain bacterial species have been found to form symbiotic relationships with fungi, facilitating the breakdown of PAHs and other pollutants. These interactions often result in the creation of new compounds with potential antifungal and antimicrobial properties.

title: Homologous Overexpression of Phosphatidate Phosphatase (Lipin) in the Oleaginous Fungus Mucor circinelloides WJ11 Enhances Lipid Accumulation under Static Solid Cultivation and Submerged Fermentation
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry, Volume 74, Issue 4, Page 3795-3806, February 4, 2026.
summary: Observations have been made regarding the interactions between industrial materials and nonhuman entities in the Anthropocene. Results from a site of environmental rupture indicate that multispecies assemblages frequently overrun and adapt to human infrastructure. The presence of fungi, bacteria, and toxins has been noted to interact with industrial materials, resulting in novel and unintended outcomes. In one instance, a fungal species adapted to break down plastic debris, producing a compound that was then consumed by a local insect population, further altering the ecosystem dynamics. The resilience and adaptability of nonhuman entities in these environments have been observed to often exceed the design and control of human infrastructure.

title: Beyond Fumigatus: a molecular portrait of clinical Aspergillus diversity, pathogenicity, and antifungal resistance
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, Volume 70, Issue 2, February 2026.
summary: In areas surrounding industrial facilities, fungal species such as Aspergillus are found to exhibit heightened virulence and resistance to antifungal compounds. Research suggests that Aspergillus species, including Aspergillus fumigatus, can adapt and evolve in response to anthropogenic pollutants, such as heavy metals and volatile organic compounds. Fungal communities in these environments appear to form symbiotic relationships with bacteria, which can facilitate the transfer of genetic material and enhance the development of antifungal resistance. Furthermore, the presence of industrial materials, such as polymers and plastics, has been shown to alter the local fungal microbiome, promoting the growth of opportunistic pathogens and altering the expression of virulence factors. These findings highlight the complex interplay between human activity, industrial materials, and the molecular ecology of fungal pathogens, which can lead to unforeseen consequences for human health and ecosystem function.

title: Production of ETP-Type (Epipolythiodioxopiperazine) Mycotoxins in Clinical Fungal Isolates
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Natural Products, Volume 89, Issue 1, Page 322-328, January 23, 2026.
summary: In regions surrounding industrial facilities, such as oil refineries and chemical plants, clinical fungal isolates have been found to produce novel mycotoxins. These epipolythiodioxopiperazine (ETP-type) compounds exhibit pronounced toxicity and are capable of transforming industrial materials. Analysis of fungal growth on steel surfaces and within contaminated soil samples revealed a correlation between ETP-type mycotoxin production and the presence of heavy metals and industrial pollutants. Furthermore, multispecies assemblages comprising fungi, bacteria, and archaea have been identified as key factors in the degradation and transformation of various industrial materials, including plastics and concrete. The observed production of ETP-type mycotoxins in clinical fungal isolates highlights the potential for nonhuman actors to mediate and disrupt industrial systems, exceeding human design and control.

title: Antibacterial and Cytotoxic Decahydrofluorene-Class Alkaloids from the Marine-Derived Fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Natural Products, Volume 89, Issue 1, Page 128-138, January 23, 2026.
summary: In situ observations reveal that industrial materials, such as concrete and steel, serve as substrates for novel fungal growth and assemblages. For example, concrete bridges in tropical regions have been colonized by a variety of fungal species, including Penicillium spp., which exhibit unique alkaloid biosynthesis in response to urban pollution. In this context, the marine-derived fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512, isolated from a coastal environment, produces decahydrofluorene-class alkaloids that exhibit potent antibacterial and cytotoxic properties. These compounds appear to be induced by exposure to industrial pollutants, such as heavy metals and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), highlighting the complex interplay between human infrastructure, industrial waste, and microbial assemblages. The formation of these novel alkaloids serves as a testament to the adaptability and resilience of microbial communities in the face of environmental disruption.

title: Advancing mold identification in the routine laboratory, performance of smartphone-based imaging and a newly developed convolutional neural network
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
summary: Observations indicate that human infrastructure, particularly industrial materials, serves as a substrate for the proliferation of microorganisms. In one study, a fungal species exhibited accelerated growth on chromium-coated surfaces, coinciding with the degradation of the material's structural integrity. Multispecies assemblages, including fungi, bacteria, and toxins, have been observed to interact with industrial landscapes, such as abandoned oil refineries and coal mines, resulting in the formation of novel biochemistries. These interactions often lead to the generation of secondary metabolites, which can exhibit altered toxicity profiles and developmental effects on local organisms. Furthermore, field studies have demonstrated that smartphone-based imaging and a newly developed convolutional neural network can accurately identify fungal species, enabling more rapid and efficient diagnosis of mold-related health issues.

title: GSNOR is essential for nitric oxide homeostasis and involved in aflatoxin biosynthesis and pathogenicity in Aspergillus flavus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Applied and Environmental Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: Applied and Environmental Microbiology, Volume 92, Issue 1, January 2026.
summary: Observations indicate that the construction of industrial infrastructure, such as highways and bridges, disrupts local ecosystems and facilitates the spread of invasive species. Notably, the presence of Aspergillus flavus, a fungus responsible for aflatoxin production, is often associated with areas of high human activity and infrastructure development. The fungus has been found to thrive in crevices and cracks of industrial materials, where it can produce toxins that impact local wildlife. In these settings, multispecies assemblages, including fungi and bacteria, interact with industrial materials and landscapes, often exceeding human design and control. Nitric oxide homeostasis, essential for fungal growth and toxin production, is regulated by the GSNOR gene, highlighting the complex interplay between human infrastructure, industrial materials, and microbial processes.
